content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Fred McFeely Rogers, born in 1928 in Latrobe, Pennsylvania, was raised in an environment that valued education and fostered an active imagination. He earned a bachelor's degree in music composition at Rollins College in 1951 and later worked for NBC television in New York. Rogers studied child development, attended Pittsburgh Theological Seminary, and became ordained as a Presbyterian minister. In 1953, he began producing the television program "The Children's Corner". Fred Rogers produced "The Children's Corner", a live variety show that won the Sylvania Award in 1955. He introduced puppet characters like King Friday XIII and Daniel Striped Tiger on this program. Later, he created and hosted "Mister Rogers' Neighborhood" on PBS from 1968 to 2001, inviting both adults and children to his show. Fred Rogers invited both adults and children to engage their imaginations through stories, songs, and puppets on "Mister Rogers' Neighborhood". The show taught children about being a good neighbor, sharing, and expressing emotions. It was the longest-running program on PBS, filmed in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and featured a caring, genuine spirit. Fred Rogers' caring, genuine spirit was reflected in "Mister Rogers' Neighborhood," a nurturing and educational program for children. Each episode was carefully crafted to convey wholesome messages. Fred Rogers was appointed Chairman of the Forum on Mass Media and Child Development in 1968, winning multiple Emmy Awards and Lifetime Achievement Awards. Fred Rogers, known for his show "Mister Rogers' Neighborhood," won numerous awards including Emmys, Peabody Awards, and the Presidential Medal of Honor. He connected with children emotionally and intellectually, teaching them self-worth and empathy. The President is authorized to award a posthumous gold medal to Fred Rogers. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike the medal with suitable emblems. Duplicates in bronze may be sold, and the medals are considered national medals. Funding for this initiative is also addressed. SEC. 5. FUNDING. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund is authorized to cover costs up to $30,000 for the medals. Proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will go back into the Fund.
